subsection.title: Tables, Graphs and Equations
subsection.p: The first step in creating a model is to describe relationships between variables. In , we analyzed the relationship between Delbert's sales and his income. Starting from a verbal description, we represented the relationship in three different ways.

li.p: A table of valuestable of values displays specific data points with precise numerical values.
A graphgraph is a visual display of the data. It is easier to spot trends and describe the overall behavior of the variables from a graph.
An algebraic equationalgebraic equation is a compact summary of the model. It can be used to analyze the model and to make predictions

subsection.p: We begin our study of modeling with some examples of linear modelslinear models. In the examples that follow, observe the interplay among the three modeling tools, and how each contributes to the model.

statement.p: Annelise is on vacation at a seaside resort. She can rent a bicycle from her hotel for 3 an hour, plus a 5 insurance fee. (A fraction of an hour is charged as the same fraction of 3.)

li.p: Make a table of values showing the cost, C, of renting a bike for various lengths of time, t.
Plot the points on a graph. Draw a curve through the data points.
Write an equation for C in terms of t.

To find the cost, we multiply the time by 3, and add the result to the 5 insurance fee. For example, the cost of a 1-hour bike ride is \text{Cost}\amp=(\$5\text{ insurance fee})+(\$3\text{ per hour})\times(\alert{1}\text{ hour}) C\amp=5+3(\alert{1})=8 A 1-hour bike ride costs 8. We record the results in a table, as shown here:

sidebyside.p: Each pair of values represents a point on the graph. The first value gives the horizontal coordinate of the point, and the second value gives the vertical coordinate. The points lie on a straight line, as shown in the figure. The line extends infinitely in only one direction, because negative values of t do not make sense here.

li.p: To write an equation, we let C represent the cost of the rental, and we use t for the number of hours:

md.mrow: \text{Cost}\amp=(\$5\text{ insurance fee})+(\$3\text{ per hour})\times\text{(number of hours)}

statement.p: Use the equation C=5+3\cdot t you found in to answer the following questions. Then show how to find the answers by using the graph.

li.p: How much will it cost Annelise to rent a bicycle for 6 hours?
How long can Annelise bicycle for 18.50?

We substitute t=\alert{6} into the expression for C to find C=5+3(\alert{6})=23A 6-hour bike ride will cost 23. The point P on the graph in the figure represents the cost of a 6-hour bike ride. The value on the C-axis at the same height as point P is 23, so a 6-hour bike ride costs 23.

sidebyside.p: We substitute C=\alert{18.50} into the equation and solve for t. \alert{18.50}\amp=5+3t 13.50\amp=3t t\amp=4.5 For 18.50 Annelise can bicycle for 4½ hours. The point Q on the graph represents an 18.50 bike ride. The value on the t-axis below point Q is 4.5, so 18.50 will buy a 4.5 hour bike ride.

In part (b) we were given a value of C and we solved the equation C=5+3t to find t.

subsection.title: Choosing Scales for the Axes
subsection.p: To create a useful graph, we must choose appropriate scales for the axes.

li.p: The axes must extend far enough to show the values of the variables.
The tick marks should be equally spaced.
Usually we should use no more than 10 or 15 tick marks.

statement.p:
In 1990, the median price of a home in the US was 92,000. The median price increased by about 4700 per year over the next decade.
Make a table of values showing the median price of a house in 1990, 1994, 1998, and 2000.
Choose suitable scales for the axes and plot the values you found in part (a) on a graph. Use t, the number of years since 1990, on the horizontal axis and the price of the house, P, on the vertical axis. Draw a curve through the points.
Write an equation that expresses P in terms of t.
How much did the price of the house increase from 1990 to 1996? Illustrate the increase on your graph.

li.p: In 1990 the median price was 92,000. Four years later, in 1994, the price had increased by \alert{4}(4700)=18,800 dollars, so P=92,000+\alert{4}(4700)=110,800 In 1998 the price had increased by \alert{8}(4700)=37,600 dollars, so P=92,000+\alert{8}(4700)=129,600 You can verify the price of the house in 2000 by a similar calculation.

We let t stand for the number of years since 1990, so that t=0 in 1990, t=4 in 1994, and so on. To choose scales for the axes, we look at the values in the table. For this graph we scale the horizontal axis, or t-axis, in 1-year intervals and the vertical axis, or P-axis, for 90,000 to 140,000 in intervals of 5,000. The points in . lie on a straight line.
Look back at the calculations in part (a). The price of the house started at 92,000 in 1990 and increased by t \times 4700 dollars after t years. Thus, P=92,000+4700t
Find the points on the graph for 1990 and 1996.

These points lie above t=0 and t=6 on the t-axis. Now find the values on the P-axis corresponding to the two points. The values are P=92,000 in 1990 and P=120,200 in 1996. The increase in price is the difference of the two P-values.
\text{increase in price}\amp=120,200-92,000 \amp=28,200 The price of the home increased 28,200 between 1990 and 1996. This increase is indicated by the arrows in .

subsection.title: Linear Equations
subsection.p: All the models in the preceding examples have equations with a similar form: y=\text{(starting value)}+\text{(rate of change)}\cdot x (We'll talk more about rate of change in .) Their graphs were all portions of straight lines. For this reason such equations are called linear equationslinear equations. The order of the terms in the equation does not matter. For example, the equation in , C=5+3t can be written equivalently as -3t+C=5 and the equation in , P=92,000+4700t can be written as -4700t +P=92,000 This form of a linear equation, Ax+By=C , is called the general formgeneral form.

assemblage.title: General Form for a Linear Equation
assemblage.p: The graph of any equation Ax+By=C where A and B are not both equal to zero, is a straight line.

subsection.title: Intercepts
subsection.p: Consider the graph of the equation 3x-4y=12 shown in . The points where the graph crosses the axes are called the interceptsintercepts of the graph. The coordinates of these points are easy to find.

paragraphs.p: The y-coordinate of the x-intercept is zero, so we set y=\alert{0} in the equation to get 3(\alert{0})-4x\amp=12x=-3
The x-intercept is the point (-3,0). Also, the x-coordinate of the y-intercept is zero, so we set x=\alert{0} in the equation to get 3y-4(\alert{0})=12y=4 The y-intercept is (0,4).

assemblage.title: Intercepts of a Graph
assemblage.p:
The points where a graph crosses the axes are called the intercepts of the graphintercepts of the graph.
To find the y-intercept, set x=0 and solve for y.
To find the x-intercept, set y=0 and solve for x

subsection.p: The intercepts of a graph tell us something about the situation it models.

li.p:
An equation for the concentration of toxic chemicals is C=285-15t To find the C-intercept, set t equal to zero.
C=285-15(\alert{0})=285 The C-intercept is the point (0, 285), or simply 285. To find the t-intercept, set C equal to zero and solve for t.

subsection.title: Intercept Method for Graphing Lines
subsection.p: Because we really only need two points to graph a linear equation, we might as well find the intercepts first and use them to draw the graph. The values of the intercepts will also help us choose suitable scales for the axes. It is always a good idea to find a third point as a check.

li.p: Find the x- and y-intercepts of the graph of 150x - 180y = 9000.
Use the intercepts to graph the equation. Find a third point as a check.
To find the x-intercept, we set y = \alert{0}.
The x-intercept is the point (60, 0). To find the y-intercept, we set x = \alert{0}.
The y-intercept is the point (0, -50).

We scale both axes in intervals of 10 and then plot the two intercepts, (60, 0) and (0, -50). We draw the line through them, as shown in . Finally, we find another point and check that it lies on this line. We choose x = \alert{20} and solve for y. 150(\alert{20}) -180y \amp = 9000 3000 -180y \amp = 9000 -180y \amp = 6000 y \amp =-33.\overline{3}
We plot the point (20, -33\frac{1}{3}). Because this point lies on the line, we can be reasonably confident that our graph is correct.

subsection.p: The examples in this section model simple linear relationships between two variables. Such relationships, in which the value of one variable is determined by the value of the other, are called functionsfunctions. We will study various kinds of functions throughout the course.
